passages.text: European Basic Materials and Industrials
In this note, we highlight recent newsws from the European Basic Materials and Industrials sectors. We also provide an updated summary model for Guala Closure ahead of Q2 2025 results.

PROGRP (OW)- Solid Q2 2025 results.ProGroup reported EBITDA of 38mup \(+97\%\) YoY (vs.1.9m in Q2 2024 and vs.JPMe of33m) due to higher average selling prices for corrugated board coupled with lower energy costs. FCF was negative at \(- 12m\) and net debt increased slightly to 853m from 848m last quarter, translating into net leverage of 5.3x vs.6.0x in March 2025 and 6.0x one year ago. The group guided for slightly higher volumes YoY in Q3 2025. For FY 2025, management expects a significant improvement in earnings compared to 2024. Finally, the company commented it remains fully committed to its long- term net leverage target (3.0x).

CANPCK (N)- Soft Q2 2025 results. Canpack reported Q2 2025 adjusted EBITDA of \(143m\) (vs. \(175m\) for Q2 2024 and vs. JPMe of \(148m\) ), down \(- 18\%\) YoY driven by higher labor costs, increasing aluminum conversion costs and incremental logistics expenses to support the growth of Indian operations. FCF was negative at \(- 516m\) due mainly to net working capital headwinds and net leverage increased to 2.5x as of June 2025 (vs. 2.2x in March 2025 and vs. 2.7x a year ago).

KPERST (N)- Secures €112m bridge loan amid restructuring discussions. Kloeckner Pentaplast has secured a €112m bridge loan from its first lien creditors to support its expenses and facilitate a restructuring deal, according to 9fin. The move comes after the company reportedly abandoned an earlier proposal to amend and extend its debt obligations due to declining earnings. According to a Bloomberg article, KPERST will report FY 2024 EBITDA of \(- 234m\) and expects FY 2025 EBITDA of \(- 200m\) . This compares to EBITDA of €241m in 2023 and €263m in 2022. The bridge loan also requires Kloeckner to restructure in a jurisdiction acceptable to its first lien lenders.

TREYELE (OW)- Solid FQ3 FY2024/25 results.TK Elevator reported FQ3 2024/25 adjusted EBITDA of €420m, up \(+9\%\) YoY (vs. €387m in FQ3 2023/24) due primarily to increasing margins. FCF was €174m in FQ3 2024/25 and net debt declined to \(- 9.1bn\) (vs. \(- 9.5bn\) in March 2025) translating into net leverage of 5.7x as of June 2025 vs. 6.1x in March 2025 and 6.6x a year ago. The group also confirmed it expects to realize pro forma EBITDA of €1.65bn by September 2026.

J.P. Morgan does and seeks to do business with companies covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.

- PRFINE (N) - Weak Q2 2025 results. Profine reported adjusted EBITDA of €28m (vs. €35m in Q2 2024 and JPME €35m), down -18% YoY due primarily to higher costs. FCF was €1m and net debt stood at €454m as of June 2025 (vs. €450m as of March 2025) translating into net leverage of 4.1x vs. 3.8x as of March 2025 and vs. 3.6x a year ago. The outlook for FY 2025 remains cautious and management does not anticipate a significant recovery in global demand due to ongoing uncertainties. The group expects a stable market in Europe in 2025, with a more noticeable demand upturn anticipated in 2026. During the earnings call, management commented that it expects Q3 2025 EBITDA to remain under pressure due to the increased cost base (linked to its Turkey and US projects). The group expects these projects to start contributing to earnings from Q2 2026.

- LNZING (OW) - Weak Q2 2025 results; encouraging FY 2025 guidance. Arxada reported Q2 2025 adjusted EBITDA of CHF85m (vs. our estimate of CHF89m), down -10% YoY driven mainly by lower volumes due to shutdowns and disruptions at the Visp Site, as well as FX headwinds. We note that excluding one-offs at the Visp site, Q2 2025 adjusted EBITDA would have increased +2% YoY on a constant exchange rate basis. FCF was negative at -CHF59m but net debt decreased slightly to -CHF3.3bn as of June 2025 (due to FX headwinds) vs. -CHF3.4bn as of March 2025 translating into net leverage (including leases) of 9.1x, unchanged vs. last quarter and vs. 10.0x a year ago. Liquidity stood at CHF158m (CHF86m cash and CHF72m available RCF). During its earnings call the company commented it expects mid-single digit sales growth (excluding FX) in 2025, as well as EBITDA growth YoY. The group also expects improved liquidity in H2 2025 due mainly to a reversal in net working capital.

- KEMONE (UW) - Very weak Q2 2025 results. Kem One reported Q2 2025 adjusted EBITDA of €1m, down -95% YoY vs. €22m in Q2 2024 driven by significantly lower volumes (especially in caustic soda down -26% YoY), increased energy costs, and technical delays in ramping up the Elyse Fos project. FCF was negative at -€41m and net debt increased to €583m as of June 2025 vs. €519m in March 2025. Total liquidity was weak at €97m (comprising gross cash of €47m and €50m in undrawn facilities. The CEO of Kem One, Paolo Barbieri, announced that he has decided "together with the shareholders and the board" to step down from his role. The Chairman of the Board, Laurent Lenoir, has agreed to serve as interim CEO while the Board undertakes a formal CEO search process to identify a permanent successor.

- CABBCO (Q) In-line Q2 2025 results; FY 2025 guidance unchanged. CABB Chemicals reported Q2 2025 adjusted EBITDA of €31m (vs. €23m in Q2 2024), up +33% YoY driven by higher volumes in the Exclusives segment as well as lower costs. FCF was negative at -€25m (due mainly to a NWC outflow) and net debt increased to -€679m as of June 2025 vs. €665m as of March 2025 and €671m a year ago, translating into net leverage of 5.8x as of June 2025 vs. 6.0x a quarter ago and 5.2x a year ago. Liquidity was €118m as of June 2025 (vs. €149m as of March 2025) with €31m in cash and €87m in undrawn facilities. For FY 2025 the company still expects adjusted EBITDA to "remain broadly in line with" the prior year, with Q3 2025 expected to be lower than Q3 2024 and Q4 2025 above Q4 2024 levels.

- PLYIM (OW) - In-line Q2 2025 results. Polynt reported Q2 2025 EBITDA of €124m down -10% YoY and inline with JPME of €124m driven by lower volumes (down -10% YoY). FCF was -€32m (including a €4m working capital inflow), and net debt decreased to €1.24bn in June 2025 vs. €1.31bn in March 2025 (helped by FX impact on debt) translating into net leverage of 2.7x vs. 2.8x one quarter ago and 2.7x one year ago.

SNFF (OW) - Soft Q2 2025 results. SNFFported Q2 2025 EBITDA of €213m (vs. €220m in Q2 2024), down - 3% YoY due mainly to higher costs especially in Europe and FX impact (we note volumes were up 4% YoY). FCF was negative at - €12m and net debt increased to €1.51bn as of June 2025 (€1.48bn last quarter), translating into net leverage of 1.7x vs. 1.6x in March 2025 and 1.8% last year. During its earnings call, the company commented that it expects lower volumes in Q3 2025 and sees gross profit trending down. The company also commented that it expects to come to market most likely next year to address its maturities in 2027 (notes) and 2026 (loan).

- AIFP (OW) - New acquisition to be financed with bonds. Air Liquide announced that it has signed a binding agreement with Macquarie Asia-Pacific Infrastructure Fund 2, for the acquisition of DIG Airgas (a leading national player in industrial gasses in South Korea), for an EV of €2.85bn (approximately 20x pre-synergies acquisition multiple; 0.4x AIFP EBITDA). The company commented that the acquisition will be made with a structured bridge loan which will be refinanced by issuing bonds. The deal is expected to close in H1 2026.

- AALLN (N) - Likely to start arbitration process for coal assets sale termination. Anglo American has responded to Peabody's announcement terminating the purchase process of its coal assets. The company commented it is confident the fire at Moranbah North in March does not constitute a material adverse change. "We are confident in our legal position and will shortly initiate an arbitration to seek damages for wrongful termination."

- BHP (N) - In-line H2 2024/25 results; net debt target increased. BHP reported H2 FY2023/24 EBITDA of \(\sim\) \$13.6bn (vs \$15.1bn in H2 FY2023/24), down 10% primarily due to lower commodity prices. FCF was \(\sim\) \$2.2bn and net debt increased to \(\sim\) \$12.9bn as of June 2025 vs. \$11.8bn in December 2024, translating into net leverage of \(\sim\) 0.5x as of June 2025 (vs. \(\sim\) 0.4x in December 2024 and \(\sim\) 0.3x in June 2024). The company increased its net debt target range to \$10-20bn from \$5-15bn in order to "assist in funding [its] suite of high-quality organic growth projects while [it] continue[s] to deliver attractive shareholder returns." BHP also successfully priced €1.4bn in new notes consisting of €800m 3.180% senior unsecured notes due September 2031; and €600m 3.643% senior unsecured notes due September 2035.

Analyst Certification: The Research Analyst(s) denoted by an "AC" on the cover of this report certifies (or, where multiple Research Analysts are primarily responsible for this report, the Research Analyst denoted by an "AC" on the cover or within the document individually certifies, with respect to each security or issuer that the Research Analyst covers in this research) that: (1) all of the views expressed in this report accurately reflect the Research Analyst's personal views about any and all of the subject securities or issuers; and (2) no part of any of the Research Analyst's compensation was, is, or will be directly or indirectly related to the specific recommendations or views expressed by the Research Analyst(s) in this report. For all Korea-based Research Analysts listed on the front cover, if applicable, they also certify, as per KOFIA requirements, that the Research Analyst's analysis was made in good faith and that the views reflect the Research Analyst's own opinion, without undue influence or intervention.

All authors named within this report are Research Analysts who produce independent research unless otherwise specified. In Europe, Sector Specialists (Sales and Trading) may be shown on this report as contacts but are not authors of the report or part of the Research Department.

A history of J.P. Morgan investment recommendations disseminated during the preceding 12 months can be accessed on the Research & Commentary page of http://www.jpmorganmarkets.com where you can also search by analyst name, sector or financial instrument.

J.P. Morgan uses a bond- level rating system that incorporates valuations (relative value) and our fundamental view on the security. Our fundamental credit view of an issuer is based on the company's underlying credit trends, overall creditworthiness and our opinion on whether the issuer will be able to service its debt obligations when they become due and payable. We analyze, among other things, the company's cash flow capacity and trends and standard credit ratios, such as gross and net leverage, interest coverage and liquidity ratios. We also analyze profitability, capitalization and asset quality, among other variables, when assessing financials. Analysts also rate the issuer, based on the rating of the benchmark or representative security. Unless we specify a different recommendation for the company's individual securities, an issuer recommendation applies to all of the bonds at the same level of the issuer's capital structure. We may also rate certain loans and preferred securities, as applicable. This report also sets out within it the material underlying assumptions used. We use the following ratings for bonds (issues), issuers, loans, and preferred securities: Overweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to outperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark); Neutral (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to perform in line with the relevant index, sector, or benchmark); and Underweight (over the next three months, the recommended risk position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector, or benchmark). J.P. Morgan Emerging Markets Sovereign Research uses Marketweight, which is equivalent to Neutral. NR is Not Rated. In this case, J.P. Morgan has removed the rating for this particular security or issuer because of either a lack of a sufficient fundamental basis or for legal, regulatory or policy reasons. The previous rating no longer should be relied upon. An NR designation is not a recommendation or a rating. NC is Not Covered. An NC designation is not a rating or a recommendation. For CDS, we use the following rating system: Long Risk (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to exceed the relevant index, sector or benchmark); Neutral (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to match the relevant index, sector or benchmark); and Short Risk (over the next three months, the credit return on the recommended position is expected to underperform the relevant index, sector or benchmark).
